facts.text: Appellant, a legal practitioner residing within Kendrapara Municipality and practising as mukhtar in criminal and revenue courts, filed nomination paper for election as Councillor on 15th March 1951.

Nomination paper rejected by Election Officer on 25th March 1951 on ground that appellant employed as legal practitioner against Municipality in case US 198 of Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act pending in Sub-Divisional Magistrate Court.

Appellant filed petition before High Court of Orissa under Article 226 on 4th April 1951 praying for writ of prohibition against State Government and Election Officer restraining election to Kendrapara Municipality under Orissa Municipal Act 1950 or Municipal Election Rules 1950.
High Court rejected petition but granted certificate under Article 132(1) for appeal to Supreme Court. High Court judgment dated 18th April 1951 in Judicial Case No. 60 of 1951.
Orissa Municipal Act 1950 (Orissa Act 23 of 1950) received assent of Governor on 7th November 1950, published in gazette on 11th November 1950.
Section 1(3) of Act: Comes into force in areas on dates appointed by State Government.
Section 16(ix): No person qualified for election if employed as paid legal practitioner on behalf of Municipality or as legal practitioner against Municipality.

Secretary to Government, Local Self-Government Dept letter No. 1336/L.S.G. dated 11th November 1950 to District Magistrates intimating general elections on adult suffrage in 12 municipalities including Kendrapara.
Notification No. 2015 L.S.G. dated 13th December 1950 under s.13 r/w s.1(3) fixing 1st March 1951 as relevant date for voters' residential qualification.
Notification No. 65 L.S.G. dated 4th January 1951 publishing Municipal Election Rules 1950 under clauses (1) and (2) of sub-s.(2) s.387.
Redistribution of wards by Notification No. 167 L.S.G. dated 10th January 1951.
Notifications Nos. 519 and 521 L.S.G. dated 24th January 1951 fixing number of Councillors and reserved seats.
15th March 1951 fixed for filing nominations, 25th March 1951 for scrutiny, 20th April 1951 for holding election.
Act extended to Kendrapara Municipality by notification under s.1(3) on 15th April 1951.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Orissa Municipal Act 1950 had come into operation in Kendrapara Municipality before 15th April 1951 such that disqualification under s.16(ix) applied to nomination filed on 15th March 1951, validating rejection on 25th March 1951 and election process.
Whether disqualification under s.16(ix) violates fundamental rights under Article 14 and Article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act had not come into operation in Kendrapara till 15th April 1951; disqualification under s.16(ix) could not have been incurred on 15th March 1951 when nomination filed; rejection illegal; election could not be held under Act or Rules.
Disqualification under s.16(ix) violates Articles 14 and 19(1)(g); arbitrary classification; other categories with conflict of interest not disqualified e.g. clients litigating against Municipality.

respondent_arguments.text: Section 1(5) expressly allows elections to be held under Act before it comes into force in area, validating all preliminary steps; s.23 Orissa General Clauses Act also supports.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Orissa Municipal Act 1950 s.1(5), s.13; Orissa General Clauses Act s.23

court_reasoning.text: S.1(5) contemplates holding elections under Act before it comes into force per s.1(3); preliminary steps authorised by necessary implication; s.1(5) came into force on assent; validates all steps taken.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Elections could be held under Act but take effect only on coming into force; disqualifications attach via preliminary steps.

court_reasoning.text: S.16(ix) reasonable classification under Art.14 to ensure purity of public life by avoiding conflict between interest and duty; not arbitrary; legislation need not be all-embracing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification of legal practitioners for/against Municipality has reasonable relation to object.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of Art.19(1)(g); no fundamental right to stand for election; restriction reasonable under Art.19(5) in interests of general public.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant can practise law but must divest briefs against/for Municipality to stand.

holdings.text: Preliminary steps and disqualification under Orissa Municipal Act validly applied before full commencement per s.1(5).
Disqualification under s.16(ix) does not violate Art.14 or 19(1)(g); reasonable classification for purity of public life.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Municipal Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs commencement, disqualifications, elections; s.1(5) validates pre-commencement steps.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14 reasonable classification; Art.19(1)(g) right to practise profession; Arts.132(1),226 for appeal and writ.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa General Clauses Act, 1937
statutes_cited.relevance: Supports preliminary orders before commencement but superseded by clear s.1(5).

outcome.summary: Both contentions of appellant negatived; High Court order upheld; no substance in arguments regarding Act's operation or constitutional violation.

key_quotes.text: Section 1(5) having thus come into force at once on the Act having received the assent of the Governor on the 7th November, 1950, if elections were to be held under the Act before the rest of the Act came into force in any particular area, all incidental steps for the holding of such elections were certainly contemplated to be taken.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on validity of pre-commencement election steps.

key_quotes.text: The classification here is of the legal practitioners who are employed on payment on behalf of the Municipality or act against the Municipality and those legal practitioners are disqualified from standing as candidates for election. The object or purpose to be achieved is the purity of public life.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies disqualification under Art.14 as reasonable.

key_quotes.text: There is no fundamental right in any person to stand as a candidate for election to the Municipality.
key_quotes.speaker: court
